name: NewYorker
text: “If they were going to die, they were going to die screaming”: Hilton Als reflects on the riots in Brownsville, Brooklyn, after 14-year-old Richard Ross was killed by police, in 1967.  https://t.co/1UKdhlawIw

name: NewYorker
text: In his new film, Christopher Munch combines faux-archival sequences and straightforward dramatizations, playing elaborate games of historical impersonation and speculation with a restrained delight. https://t.co/RikaOsedKB

name: NewYorker
text: “Nobody ever recommended or even suggested that I be a novelist—in fact, some tried to stop me. I simply had the idea to be one, and that’s what I did,” Haruki Murakami writes. “People become runners because they’re meant to.” https://t.co/rojRnNpRpD

name: NewYorker
text: Despite an onslaught of confirmed COVID-19 cases in mid-March, Iceland never imposed a lockdown. And yet, by mid-May, the virus had virtually been eliminated in the country. How did they do it? https://t.co/hauvE0VqaA

name: NewYorker
text: Epictetus’ advice: when alone, “call it peace and liberty, and consider yourself the gods’ equal.” https://t.co/X2unO56fOK

text: “Standing by my mother’s living-room window, I tried, tentatively, to ask her why our world was burning, burning.” On this week’s episode of #NewYorkerRadio, Hilton Als reads from and discusses his recent Personal History. https://t.co/VfxwcnukKd

text: How much can we restore society to a minimal level of functioning while still controlling the coronavirus? https://t.co/dxpLFTn4oY

text: In a trailer on Mission Street, in San Francisco, meals from six different restaurants are prepared on site—the culinary equivalent of a multicolor retractable pen. https://t.co/agfH7zpb5K

text: In the Trump White House, under John Kelly, the President’s Daily Brief happened only three times a week, and sometimes less, if Trump seemed to be in a foul mood. “It was awful,” a former White House oﬃcial said. “He just rants and raves.” https://t.co/IA7MrWdwPN
